Params[3]: It's a day like any other—or at least it was supposed to be.
The boy has been reading in the storage late into the night, yet he's still yet to hear the familiar knocks coming down the ventilation duct.
Seeing that it now reads 4:00 am on his device and feeling helplessly edgy, the boy decides to crawl out of the ventilation duct and tiptoes his way back home.
With the door ajar, he sees that the lights in his mother's workspace are still on.
Badly wounded, Rachel sits before his mom with a frown on her face.
It's not the first time the Cargo Crew let things go missing.
I didn't do it this time.
Which means you've done it before?
...That's a really bad joke.
Some of the guys from before tried to rob our things, and I was the one that stopped them. I'm sure you know who I'm talking about.
I do, of course, except they all say you're the one that did the robbing this time.
Do you trust me?
Makes sense if you don't, though... I mean, you probably would have been much better off without me anyway.
Curious about what that means, the boy was about to open his mouth to ask—yet stops in his tracks. The timing isn't quite right just yet.
Do you regret all of this?
No, because the riot just had to happen.
But, look... I'm very sorry.
No, don't be. You didn't kill him. The perp took advantage of the riot.
She stops for a few moments before she continues.
...Ashlar used us all.
Used, you said...
The same way I've been using him and those good-for-nothing royals, I bet.
She says these words with sizzling anger.
But I'm not ready to turn the tables with him just yet... There are things that I just can't do without him.
But Julie, I'll never become one of them, and you know I never will...
The boy doesn't exactly understand what Rachel is saying to his mother.
But he now knows that they've been working with someone they both hate, and that there are people in the Cargo Crew who take what's not theirs.
This isn't the first time their conversation turned tense, but every time he tries to ask about it, they brush him off.

You're 11 and an adult now, the boy's mom said to the boy a while back—but when he asks her a question she doesn't want to answer, she'd go back on her words and say, "You're still too young to worry about that."
What happened to Assad?
She drops the topic and starts asking about Rachel's friend.
Assad—the boy remembers the name. He's close to Rachel and they always work and drink together.
They are so close that people won't stop teasing them.
When's the baby due?
Assad always laughs it off when he hears things like this.
You're kidding me, right? I'd find someone much more elegant if I were to date.
He's hurt and is resting.
The two of them sit silently in the swaying train for a while.
Thank you... for today.
I will definitely be more careful going forward.
Okay.
Rachel stands up and pulls open the curtains—and sees the boy hiding behind it.
...Good evening.
[—], you'll not tell anyone what you heard just now.
Okay.
I won't.
Julie, be nice to the kid.
...Come in, [—]. Time for bed.
Mom...
Did Aunt Rachel do something bad to you before?
He ventures the question.
The riot she was talking about... Is that why Dad was killed...?
Look, this isn't something...
I'm not a kid anymore!
He talks back in a lowered voice.
I can work on my own in the Maintenance Crew!
It's a lie, but the urge to know the truth drives the boy to use it as a chip for bargaining. His attempt, however, fails to fool his mother.
Work?
You think I don't know what you've been doing?

I only took her up on her proposal because she said it's too dangerous for a nine-year-old to work in the Cargo Crew, and that books can help you with learning... and that you won't come in contact with the guards if you stay there.
You should sleep now.
But...
You should sleep now.
Those words are supposed to be words of comfort—except they come out sounding like an order and trigger an explosion of all the feelings that have been bottled up inside the boy over the years.
Mom.
Yes?
People say that if Dad were still alive, he would never leave us here.
He would never let others call you a witch, or a...
Have you heard these?
Why does it matter? I'm too busy to feel bothered.
But don't you feel sad... when you hear them?
How does feeling sad help us? Is it going to change anything?
Just because it isn't going to change anything doesn't mean you don't feel sad, right?
It doesn't matter if I do... These feelings will only suffocate us.
Your father is dead... There's nothing I can do for him. I don't even have a chance to feel sad.
Looking at the boy's determined face, she keeps her cool and explains their situation to him—for the first time.
Asslam has always been in chaos. Everyone does what they can to survive this hellhole.
Some resort to violence, some to trickery, and some... can only rely on others.
Regardless of which path they pick, when the sky comes tumbling down, everyone has to bear the consequence of their choice.
She rubs her fingers on the edge of her mask. Her fingers are shaking slightly.
Rachel wants to change the status quo. At that time, as an aristocrat from the upper level, your father was part of the problem.
I begged him to change, but he died just after the riot began. Rachel didn't kill him. The perpetrator just used the chaos she caused.
There are still many more people up there like your father—or even worse than him.
He died without ever having the chance to prove that he could change, and people down here just can't be bothered to understand me.
But I can understand why they feel this way. To them, I am an "accomplice" of the aristocrats.
...Mom.
Do you hate me, [—]?
Even at the very bottom of Asslam, people wouldn't have treated you like this had you been born into a different family.
Can't we leave?
The world out there is much worse than this. The Punishing Virus has taken over the land, and you need to be around a CPF to be safe.
You can stay here because I still have a job here, but when I'm gone, you'll have to leave and join the ranks of the Scavengers if you can't fend for yourself.
When that day comes... there will be no food, no shelter, and you might get infected anytime. When you want to rest, the Corrupted and robbers will swarm up to you.
What should we do?
Trust Rachel. She has a plan to free us from this oppression.
Will she become a great leader? Just like the heroes in the books?
...Yeah...
She lets out a heavy sigh.
Are you helping her, Mom?
Yes. I'm trying to help her... I don't always agree with the way she does things, but I have no right to question her, either.
She's good at winning people over to our side—and that's just one of the things she's good at that I'm not.
She puts her hand on her mask again—to make sure it just sits safely on her face.
When I was your age, my dream was to become a merchant that brings people whatever they need.
Except...
...I realized that I had nothing to sell... but my own future.
Your future...?
She nods and hides all the scars of time behind her mask, revealing no further details.
Why do you sell your future?
To buy things that I otherwise can't afford.
For someone ordinary to become a hero, there is a steep price to pay, and it might even hurt those around you.
Those words turn into sharp knives and stab him in the heart.
[—], I've given your situation some thought over the past few days. You're no genius, and it's way too difficult for you to learn a skill on your own. You need a teacher.
Rachel will put you on her Carge Crew once you turn 13.
Like it or not, you need to learn how to keep yourself alive. Time to sleep now.
...No, I don't want to sleep. What did you mean when you just said you're selling your future? Where are you going?
You should sleep now.
Without saying another word, she drags a tattered blanket over and puts it over the boy.
Wait, you haven't answered my question!
You should sleep now.
Her lowered voice now sounds menacing.
...Are you going to stay here tonight?
She lets out a non-committal response through her mask—which is then followed by coughs.
Did you catch a cold?
She shakes her head without saying anything.
She lies down on her side next to the boy. Then, lifting her hand to touch her boy, she starts singing the same gentle lullaby that she always did many, many years ago.
～Sleep, sleep, my child,～
～For there are fireflies here that will keep your heart alight.～
～Sleep, sleep, my child,～
～May your dreams be as peaceful as the summer night...～
～May hope forever be by your side.～
～Your worries will drift with the wind.～
～And when you rise to the first light,～
～The sun will greet you with a gentle smile so bright.～
～So sleep, sleep, my child.～
～For only when you wake up free of worries～
～Can you smile at the world warmly.～
The young man wakes up from his memory—and sees that he's all alone now, having been left here by the Constructs and the commandant from last night.
From the distance, the boy can hear a Construct girl singing away as she fixes a toy with the parts she has.
Oops. Did I wake you up?
Did I fall asleep holding this pen?
Yup, and good morning.
Where are the others?
They all left on a mission.
My name is Lillian, by the way. They told me about your memory loss, and I'll be taking you to Medical Center 09 in a bit.
Medical Center 09? Someone from yesterday told me that I should go somewhere with better medical resources and get myself checked up and treated there, but they never said it's Medical Center 09.
That's what they were talking about, because that's the only place around here with better medical resources. We'll be on our way when the transport vehicle is here.
Have you recalled anything? Do you remember your name?
I've recalled a lot of things, except for my name...
Seems like you really hated your name, huh?
What makes you say so?
According to our instructor, you'll tend to have a harder time recalling something if you tried to shun it before the memory loss.
That's probably what's happening to you now, I'm guessing.
Why would I try to shun my name, though?
...Oops. Did I say something wrong?
No. I'm just feeling a little lost here.
But you said you've recalled a lot of things already, right?
But they're all from before I was 12, and they all have to do with my family and friends, and...
...And the picture books and mangas I've read.
(But why am I remembering everything I've read...)
Anything else?
Well, they're nothing worth mentioning.
I bet they're just some of the bad things you've done.
...Unfortunately, no.
Just memories of some situation we couldn't work our way around, dreams I couldn't make happen, a nice aunt who would occasionally come to my rescue, and my mom who basically never told me a thing.
Boy, those are lame with a capital L. I swear you'd be some guy if you were in a game.
I guess you're right... Say, do you think an ordinary person might just someday find himself on the wrong side of justice?
If anything, an ordinary person is exactly the type that would fall on the wrong side of justice, since they've got nothing that would help them land on the right side of it.
For someone ordinary to become a hero, there is a steep price to pay, and it might even hurt those around you.
The boy once again recalls his mother's words.
...The boy died in what little he still has of his memory—yet here it is, alive and well in this body he doesn't recognize. What price did he have to pay exactly for this miracle to have happened?
The transport vehicle is here. Here, they left your weapon here for you. Let's get going.
With her toy only half-fixed, Lillian stands up from the desk.
And it's only now that the young man sees that the toy is a firefly put together with parts.
Wait a second... Where did you get that thing you're holding?
Are you talking about this firefly toy?
I found this out there when I came.
Can I have a look? I feel like... I've seen it before...
With a worried look on her face, Lillian hands the damaged firefly toy over to the young man.
This toy is put together with gears and used lightbulbs. Here, you just need to give its head a little twist and the wings will flap away.
The body of the toy, however, is now twisted at such a weird angle that it seems as though it's been hit by something.
What's with this?
Scars are part of one's memory.
And with it, an excruciating pain spreads out from his chest with an inexplicable malice.
It's the same kind of pain that hit him when he first woke up.
...Some things are just meant to be.
